page.title: 02Landscape of Beeley Moor
page.content: This is a flat upland area with two exposed millstone grit edges from which two main valleys lead off, one in an easterly direction and the other westwards. The predominant feature is grouse moor and in places peat bogs exist. The moorland is interspersed with rough pasture for sheep grazing whilst lay pasture provides fodder for cattle. Dry-stone walls intersect the area giving a bleak appearance to the landscape. On the exposed moorland and down the gentle sided valleys are a number of coniferous plantations. There are a few small coppices of deciduous trees. The moorland is the source of two streams: the River Hipper flowing east and Beeley Brook flowing west resulting in waterfalls en route to lower ground. It is a sparsely populated area. The farms are built of local gritstone.
